awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exploring the physics of galaxy clusters with comprehensive cosmological simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
Galaxy clusters are some of the largest known structures in the universe. Modeling their growth over the age of the universe will give us insight on how matter, energy, and the laws of physics influence the universe that we see today. This project will add some more details to the computer modeling to provide better approximations to the physics governing the behavior of the gas in galaxy clusters. The results of these new models will be simulations that can be used by other researchers who are studying galaxies and galaxy clusters.

Galaxy clusters are some of the largest structures in the universe. Modeling their growth over cosmological time scales gives us insight on how dark matter, ordinary matter, and the laws of physics influence the universe that we see today. The proposed project will add more detailed physics in the form of magnetic fields, anisotropic thermal conduction, and radiative feedback from active galactic nuclei (AGN). The project will use a moving mesh code known as AREPO to perform these simulations. The simulations will follow the IllustrisTNG cosmological models with the added physics. Zoom-ins of clusters will be used to compare the effects of the new physics models and to make observational predictions for future ground and space-based observatories. At the end of the project, the data and simulations will be made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A long-standing goal of research in cosmology has been to accurately determine the overall structure and properties of the Universe. This includes, for example, the fundamental cosmological parameters, such as the expansion rate at the present day (the Hubble parameter), the nature of dark matter and dark energy, and whether general relativity is the correct description of gravity on the largest scales. Ongoing and planned projects, such as Euclid, the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI), the Roman Space Telescope, and the Vera Rubin Observatory have the ambitious goals of measuring these quantities to 1% accuracy, or better.  These surveys will map out e.g. the distribution of galaxies throughout most of cosmic time, which will enable, in principle, 1% determinations of these fundamental parameters, as well as tight constraints on the masses of neutrinos and the nature of dark energy.

Interpretation of the data from these missions will rely on computer simulations that make predictions for the distribution of matter in the Universe for adopted values of the quantities to be inferred. The approach to doing so up to now has been to reply on simulations that only follow the dark matter, which makes up the vast majority of mass in the Universe. However, simulations that include the ordinary matter that stars and the luminous parts of galaxies has shown that effects within galaxies that release large quantities of energy, such as supernovae and energy from accreting supermassive black holes, can influence the distribution of matter at a level much larger than 1%, at least over some scales. However, our understanding of these effects has been limited up to now by the relatively small volumes covered by the computationally expensive simulations that capture these “feedback” effects.

In one phase of our project, we have completed a new suite of simulations that comprise the “MillenniumTNG Project.” These simulations include all the various components of the real Universe, including ordinary matter, dark matter, and dark energy, and make predictions for the properties of galaxies and the large-scale distribution of matter, in much larger volumes than in earlier studies. Preliminary results obtained during the course of our award from these new simulations demonstrate their power in being able to provide new insights into how the uncertain feedback processes can affect galaxies and how they are distributed on the largest scales relevant to the ongoing observational studies. From this work, we will quantify how important these effects are for particular cosmological observables and how to account for them in interpreting the new data so that the dream of precision cosmology can be achieved.
